When the great king ascended the jeweled throne, he widely saved all beings,
Oil-clouds covered the eight directions, and the universal rain filled and moistened everywhere.
The great king governs the common people, universally ending all violence and cruelty,
Punishments and prisons all cease, and the orphaned and alone are all at ease.
In the past, all beings each harmed one another,
Drinking blood and eating flesh, now all give rise to compassionate thoughts.
In the past, all beings were poor and had few clothes,
Covering themselves with grass, hungry and emaciated like hungry ghosts.
When the great king arose in the world, glutinous rice grew naturally,
From the trees came wonderful clothes, and men and women were all adorned.
In the past, they competed for trivial benefits, and with unrighteousness they oppressed each other;
Now, all are abundant, like strolling in Indra's garden.
In the past, people committed evil, with greed and lust arising where they did not belong,
Other people's wives and young girls, they various ways oppressed and forced them.
Now, seeing other women, upright and wonderfully adorned,
The mind is without attachment, just like the Heaven of Contentment.
In the past, all beings spoke falsely and unrealistically,
Unrighteous and without benefit, with flattery they took people's intentions.
Today, all the various beings have completely abandoned all evil speech,
Their minds are already soft and pliable, and their speech is also well-regulated.
In the past, all beings practiced various deviant dharmas,
With palms joined in respect, they bow to the cows, sheep, dogs, and pigs.
Now hearing the king's right Dharma, they awaken and remove wrong views,
Understanding that the fruits of suffering and joy all arise from causes and conditions.
Great King, your wonderful voice, those who hear it all rejoice;
The sounds of Brahma and Indra, none can compare.

The king's father was Pure Light, the king's mother was Lotus Light,
When the five turbidities appeared, they took the throne and ruled the world.
At that time there was a vast garden, in the garden there were five hundred ponds,
Each surrounded by a thousand trees, each covered with flowers.
On the banks of the ponds, they built a thousand-pillared hall,
Adorned with railings and so forth, all complete.
In the evil Dharma of the end times, for many years it did not rain,
The pond waters all dried up, the grasses and trees all withered.
Seven days before the king's birth, auspicious spiritual signs first appeared;
Those who saw it all thought:
The savior will now appear in the world.
At that time, in the middle of the night, the great earth shook in six ways;
In a jeweled flower pond, light appeared like the sun.
In the five hundred ponds, merit and virtue filled the water;
Dry trees all sprouted branches, flowers and leaves became luxuriant.
When the pond water was full, it flowed everywhere;
It reached all places in JambudvÄ«pa, none were not moistened.
Medicinal herbs and all trees, hundreds of grains and seedlings,
Branches, leaves, flowers, fruits and grains, all became abundant.
Ditches, pits, mounds, and various high and low places,
In this way, all the land was not level.
Thorns, sand, gravel, and all kinds of impurities,
All in a single thought, turned into various precious jewels.
When sentient beings saw this, they rejoiced and praised,
All saying they had gained good benefits, like a thirsty person drinking delicious water.
At that time, King PrabhÄvat, with his immeasurable retinue,

In the five hundred ponds, there was a pond named Joyful,
Above the pond was a Dharma hall where the father king resided.
The former king said to the queen:
I recall seven nights ago, in the middle of the night the earth shook and quaked, and there was light appearing here.
At that time, in the flower pond, a lotus flower with a thousand petals emerged,
Its light shining like a thousand suns, reaching up to the peak of Mount Sumeru.
It was made of vajra for its stem, the finest gold for its platform,
And various jewels for its petals, with wonderful fragrance for its stamens and pistils.
The king was born on top of that flower, sitting upright with his legs crossed,
Adorned with excellent characteristics, revered by celestial spirits.
The king was greatly delighted, entered the pond to embrace him himself,
and handed him to the queen, saying:
You should rejoice, your son!
Treasure troves all emerged, and marvelous garments grew on wish-fulfilling trees,
Celestial music played beautiful sounds, filling the sky.
All sentient beings gave rise to great joy,
Joining palms, they exclaimed in wonder:
Excellent! Savior of the world!
At that time, the king emitted a radiant light that universally illuminated all,
Causing the four continents to have darkness dispelled and illnesses cured.
Yakshas, pishachas, poisonous insects, and ferocious beasts,
Those who wished to harm people all hid themselves.
Bad reputation, loss of good benefits, and unexpected troubles and illnesses,
Such sufferings were eliminated, and everyone rejoiced.
All kinds of sentient beings, looking at each other like parents,
Abandoning evil, giving rise to a compassionate mind, single-mindedly seeking omniscience.
Shutting the doors to the evil destinies, revealing the paths to humans and gods,
Proclaiming omniscience, liberating all beings.
We see the great king, universally obtaining good benefits,
Those without refuge or guidance, all attaining peace and happiness.'

The beings that King Mahaprabha guided with the four means of magnetizing are none other than all the bodhisattvas in this assembly, who have attained irreversibility from supreme perfect enlightenment, abiding on the first ground up to the tenth ground, possessing various great vows, gathering various aids to the path, cultivating various wondrous practices, perfecting various adornments, attaining various supernormal powers, and abiding in various liberations, dwelling in various wondrous Dharma palaces in this assembly.
At that time, the night spirit Blossoming Flowers on All Trees, in order to extensively proclaim the meaning of this liberation for the youth Sudhana, spoke a verse, saying:
I have a vast eye that universally sees the ten directions,
All the oceans of lands, those who transmigrate through the five destinies.
I also see those buddhas sitting under the bodhi tree,
With spiritual powers pervading the ten directions, teaching the Dharma to liberate sentient beings.
I have pure ears, universally hearing all sounds,
I also hear the Buddha's teachings, joyfully believing and accepting them.
I have the knowledge of others' minds, without duality, unobstructed,
In a single thought, I thoroughly understand the ocean of all minds.
I have attained the knowledge of past lives, able to know all eons,
Myself and others, distinctions all clearly understood.
In a single thought, I know the ocean of lands, as many as atoms in the cosmos,
The buddhas, bodhisattvas, and beings of the five paths.
Remembering the buddhas of the past, first giving rise to the vow of enlightenment,
Up to cultivating all practices, each and every one perfectly fulfilled.
Also knowing those buddhas accomplishing the path of enlightenment,
Using various skillful means, turning the wheel of the Dharma for the sake of beings.
Also knowing the ocean of all the buddhas' vehicles,
How long the true Dharma will remain, and how many sentient beings will be liberated.
I have cultivated this Dharma door for immeasurable eons;
I now explain it for you, Buddha's disciples, you should study it.
Good man!
I only know this bodhisattva's liberation door of vast joyful light.

Who attain pure vows and in one bodhisattva practice universally enter the ocean of all bodhisattva practices;
Who attain sovereign power and in one bodhisattva liberation door universally enter the ocean of all bodhisattva liberation doors.
How could I be able to know and explain their merits and practices?
Good man!
In this enlightenment site, there is a night spirit named
Great Vows, Diligent Effort, and Power to Rescue and Protect All Sentient Beings.
You should go ask her:
How do Bodhisattvas teach and transform sentient beings, causing them to aspire to supreme, perfect enlightenment?
How do they adorn and purify all Buddha lands?
How do they serve all Thus-Come Ones?
How do they cultivate all Buddha Dharmas?
Then, the youth Sudhana bowed his head to her feet, circumambulated her countless times, earnestly gazed up at her, took his leave, and departed.
